title: Slow clap for the Lore writers
body: Really. All props to you guys, this had been one of the best stories I have ever read, and what you guys did with Gankplank.....just wow! Congrats guys, you held up to your word, delivering a top notch lore event that will be remembered by all

replies.body: Thank you very much from everyone on the team. It means a lot.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wDajqW561KM

Some context about the clip above:

"Congratulations" is an iconic final scene of the show *Neon Genesis Evangelion*. The showmakers have ran out of time and money, and could not deliver a proper finale, airing a confusing clip show that delved deep into the psyche of the main character, ending with this scene. This only added to a complete mindfuck that this psychological thriller has delivered beforehand, but luckily the popularity of the show has blown out of proportion and the studio was able to release the ending alternative to the last two episodes, called *End of Evangelion*.

By itself the scene is... cheesy and confusing. In context, it's just absurd - watching NGE is like staring at a series of Rorscharch inkblots while on LSD.
I watched both endings and neither one really made a whole lot of sense to me. I know they're redoing/remade the show as a series of movies, but haven't watched them yet
I hope we'll see more lore outside the events
You will.

We're happy. We, the lore whiners, are having a loregasm. Job well done. You're four years late, but what's done is done. If we get one or two events this size a year, we're sort of satisfied. However, we're looking forward to the "outside of events" lore as well. Some people are extremely focused on singular characters and wish to see something about them every once in a while.

For example, I'm a Brand main, with a soft spot for Leona, Shyvana, and the other Demacians. All I know about my favourite champion is that he was imprisoned by the Demacians and he knew more about the Institute of War than the summoners let him tell to the Journal of Justice. That was years ago. Any hint on Brand's development, or even Demacia in general, would be great. That's the sort of periodical insight we've been missing since the JoJ.

Keep up the good work. Hope you're having as much fun as we do! :D

I'm sure that I'll take plenty of flak and downvotes for this, but I'm posting it anyways.

The whole thing with GP being disabled for days still leaves me with an awful taste in my mouth. Even with the essentially free skin. It was so unnecessary with far better options available that achieve the same end goal, such as enabling only his spooky skin. So thoughtless towards players who main him in ranked. So intrusive when Riot had made such a big deal in the retcon about lore not interfering with gameplay.  Why did you think that it was the only way for the event to work? I'm not looking forward to future lore events now. I'm only apprehensive towards what 'great, new idea' Riot will have for delivering lore that arbitrarily restricts players. That's what I will remember about this event. Not the stories, music, and so on, which should be the focus.

5 days, one week after his rework. You couldn't go 5 days without playing Gangplank in Ranked? If you were a Riven main I might understand, because they can't play anything else, but really? 5 days of no GP ruined this assload of epicness for you?

They deliberately lowered your expectations, made you take a little dip, let you down for a second, just to RISE OUT OF THE ASHES VICTORIOUS AND LOOKING FLY AS F#CK. In my opinion, that doesn't detract from the experience, that makes it SO MUCH BETTER. Imagine your friends tell you you're too old for a birthday party for a week before your birthday, only to throw you a massive surprise party. Is it really so bad that you felt kinda bad for a week when THIS is what you get as a payoff?

We've (Narrative) been busy on various teams, including Champion, ChampUp, Events (as you've seen in the last few weeks), Foundations, Promo and more besides. Also, we've been undergoing a serious restructuring and recruitment strategy while we also collaborate with Riot leadership to create teams that are focused on delivering story.

I understand how it looks from the outside, and it's been personally frustrating to know the pain being felt by players waiting for more story content, but we have been putting out content. We've got a long way to go, but Burning Tides: The Reckoning, and the new character introductions for Gangplank, Miss Fortune, TF, and Graves are examples of what we're aiming to do and then better in regard to quality.

We would never do such a thing. Unless it was really cool. Ok, strike my first statement.

I don't want to talk about where we'll go next as there are so many possibilities. Also, it assumes we'll go somewhere because of an Event. That's not necessarily the case.

I have really loved this lore event. It was an awesome change of pace to League in many ways, but this statement is scary to me. What constitutes cool to the lore team may or may not be cool to the people playing these champions.

Lets say they have a Piltover event where Jinx Caitlyn and Vi all 'die' in an explosion. I would be out my two best ADCs and my most played jungler. True that I would have 123 other champions to play, but even if they were only disabled for a week I would effectively be banned from ranked for that week. That is not immersive, just annoying.

Another perspective to look at it from is a new player. Players from the level ranges of 5-20 have not yet played enough to have a diversified champion pool. Any newer player with a champion the lore team has disabled for the 'cool factor' now might have a significant portion of their champion pool disabled. Hardly an incentive to keep playing if they find Riot will just take away their champions for no better reason than lore they have not yet played enough to be invested in.

This kind of thinking also disregards the financial aspects of lore disabled champions. Skins cost money. At any point in Riots history when a player acquires a skin it is done so with the knowledge they will have access to it from then on with the standing exception of being when a champion is selectively disabled due to a game breaking bug.

Is Riot now saying they will take away our ability to use products we have paid for because they believe it enhances their story telling? That is not something I am comfortable supporting as their are many games (read nearly all) that would not make this kind of statement.

Just to be clear: I wasn't referring to disabling champs at all. I was talking about physical/emotional trials in a potential story. From a purely personal perspective (disclaimer), it's unlikely we'll be disabling champs for reasons pertaining to an Event or story on any kind of regular basis, if at all. I'm not ruling it out, as I'm not speaking for Riot as a whole, but it's unlikely.

This wasn't intended to be a setting of precedent, as far as I'm aware.

EDIT: Thanks for the edit/update

I'll have a chat tomorrow with folks who are more clued in on this. I'm pretty much all about the story, and though I was involved in the discussions about what happened with GP in-game, I'm not the best person to talk about the strategy overall, particularly in regard to what it means moving forward.

Do remember that though we obfuscated the true reason for the removal of Gangplank (which was partly to introduce his new base skin, which is directly caused by the story), we didn't remove him because we actually killed him (one of the reasons he wasn't ghosted, he wasn't actually dead). We swung for the fences a bit, and took some risks. I'm very proud of the fact so many Rioters were willing to do that and have fun along with it—though I understand some players disagree and are displeased by what happened.

There will definitely be more of a full answer than I can provide you right now as we (Events team and Riot) respond to questions arising from the event, including the one you mention. Sorry I can't be more definitive right now.

I do like how this got me thinking about how the people of Bilgewater might've thought of GP's "death" by using us, the community, as a represenatation for some of it. Me personally, I was pretty shocked to hear that GP was "dead". As soon as I heard, I rushed on my mobile and read the logs on S@20 and was just so surprised. GP being "dead". Then today you guys revealed he is alive, but now more pissed then ever and I cheered. I called my buddy who plays GP and told him "GP ain't dead". My buddy's reaction "Spooky GP? No? Oh wow, that's cool." Him and I were impressed with the writing. Good job. But ya, trying to imagine some of Bilgewater's reaction to his "death" as the way the community reacted is pretty interesting imo.

Yea  I was  dumbfounded when "Gangplank is dead".

Now he's back I'm just thinking ... well, he's not going to do much other than tame or temper this self-destructing Bilgewater society, and so I was indifferent. o__o

I doubt that's the case.

Gangplank ruled Bilgewater because he was invincible.  Nobody - *nobody* - crossed him and got away with it.  He might've had some scars, but those who did it were very, very dead now because of it.

...Or that's how it *was*.  But now he's been proven beatable, and one redhead's busy offing his most loyal men.  His empire's crumbling, and even when word gets around that he didn't die, he was still *beaten*.  People aren't going to be afraid of him like they were before.  Every step of the way former allies are going to turn on him, former enemies are going to be emboldened to act against him, and he has none of the resources at his back to pull him along.

Gangplank's fight to regain Bilgewater is going to be one *hell* of a war.
